entry.title: Arts Library Open House Branding
entry.summary: For the opening house event for the Arts Library at UCLA, I volunteered to assist in making branded merch for the library for freebies during the event. Designing for potential stickers, erasers, and buttons, I created several designs for the Communications board to select for the event. In connection to the Open house event being the same week as Valentine's, this was the final decision made into stickers and buttons! (Still available as freebies today!) View the other contending designs…
entry.content:
For the opening house event for the Arts Library at UCLA, I volunteered to assist in making branded merch for the library for freebies during the event. Designing for potential stickers, erasers, and buttons, I created several designs for the Communications board to select for the event. 

In connection to the Open house event being the same week as Valentine's, this was the final decision made into stickers and buttons! (Still available as freebies today!)

View the other contending designs here.

entry.title: BruinPlanner
entry.summary: In a team of five, we interviewed five participants who were all UCLA students taking Fundamentals of User Experience to gain further insight to the usability of our product, Bruin Planner. For this portion of the project, we tested the flow of changing a course from a generated plan for the Winter 2021 term. To test this, we conducted a usability test, designing a prototype on Figma in which the interviewee was asked to complete the task by clicking through the prototype and navigating through a series of slides demonstrating BruinPlanner’s interface. This testing activity needed to be conducted in order to gain knowledge of a user’s understanding and interaction with the app to assess whether its state meets user’s expectations and goals. Conducting these interviews, we found that many interviewees used prior knowledge of class planners to navigate through BruinPlanner, hoping that the process in changing courses were more abridged and required less steps, and the amount of detailed information on a course should vary depending on the task. Based on this new insight, the development team can implement new design changes to reflect the user’s input such as minimizing the app’s interface by removing clutter and unnecessary screen confirmations to create a more streamlined process in changing their plans. In addition, the team can reflect further on our research questions that focus on four-year degree planning and explore further how it can be balanced to match user’s previous expectations in quarter-to-quarter class planning to create a more intuitive and easy experience. Over the course of this project, we learned how to conduct a productive user interview to gain intel on current student’s needs and goals, design and present a prototype, and interpret usability test reports to further develop BruinPlanner. Since the first research activity, we have updated our requirements list to include displaying only the title of the course and an option to expand and view more information, and keeping the process of customizing courses limited to 2-3 steps with no repetition or redundancy. In addition, new changes made to the root cause analysis reflect more accurately the user's ultimate goals in having a fun, engaging college experience. Along with another group member, we created low and high-fidelity wireframes for the app and making the prototype. Interact with our application…
entry.content:
In a team of five, we interviewed five participants who were all UCLA students taking Fundamentals of User Experience to gain further insight to the usability of our product, Bruin Planner. For this portion of the project, we tested the flow of changing a course from a generated plan for the Winter 2021 term. To test this, we conducted a usability test, designing a prototype on Figma in which the interviewee was asked to complete the task by clicking through the prototype and navigating through a series of slides demonstrating BruinPlanner’s interface. This testing activity needed to be conducted in order to gain knowledge of a user’s understanding and interaction with the app to assess whether its state meets user’s expectations and goals.

Conducting these interviews, we found that many interviewees used prior knowledge of class planners to navigate through BruinPlanner, hoping that the process in changing courses were more abridged and required less steps, and the amount of detailed information on a course should vary depending on the task. Based on this new insight, the development team can implement new design changes to reflect the user’s input such as minimizing the app’s interface by removing clutter and unnecessary screen confirmations to create a more streamlined process in changing their plans. In addition, the team can reflect further on our research questions that focus on four-year degree planning and explore further how it can be balanced to match user’s previous expectations in quarter-to-quarter class planning to create a more intuitive and easy experience.

Over the course of this project, we learned how to conduct a productive user interview to gain intel on current student’s needs and goals, design and present a prototype, and interpret usability test reports to further develop BruinPlanner. Since the first research activity, we have updated our requirements list to include displaying only the title of the course and an option to expand and view more information, and keeping the process of customizing courses limited to 2-3 steps with no repetition or redundancy. In addition, new changes made to the root cause analysis reflect more accurately the user's ultimate goals in having a fun, engaging college experience. 

Along with another group member, we created low and high-fidelity wireframes for the app and making the prototype. 

Low-Fidelity Wireframes

High-Fidelity Wireframes

Prototype

Interact with our application below!

entry.title: Gender and Development
entry.summary: About For the Fall Quarter '21 course Introduction to Digital Humanities, I collaborated with four other students to create a website from scratch that would be the platform for our findings while analyzing our selected dataset. For our data, we picked a dataset from the OECD’s The Gender, Institutions and Development Database from 2019, specifically examining the differences and similarities of Eastern European countries when it came to gender attitudes, such as when it comes to violence against women and political voice. I was the primary website designer, meaning I foresaw the entirety of the design process from selecting themes, selecting a color scheme, and editing the website content using Wordpress hosted by Humspace. View our team's website…
entry.content:
About 

For the Fall Quarter '21 course Introduction to Digital Humanities, I collaborated with four other students to create a website from scratch that would be the platform for our findings while analyzing our selected dataset. 
 
For our data, we picked a dataset from the OECD’s The Gender, Institutions and Development Database from 2019, specifically examining the differences and similarities of Eastern European countries when it came to gender attitudes, such as when it comes to violence against women and political voice. 
 
I was the primary website designer, meaning I foresaw the entirety of the design process from selecting themes, selecting a color scheme, and editing the website content using Wordpress hosted by Humspace. 

View our team's website here!
